conclusion: To find the power of the external force doing work, follow specific steps.
The conductor rod OC is rotating with angular velocity ω in a magnetic field B, sweeping a semi-circular path.
The induced EMF in the rod is given by the formula: 𝓔 = B ⋅ l ⋅ v.
The velocity v at the end of the rod is v = ω ⋅ r.
The induced EMF is 𝓔 = B ⋅ r^2 ⋅ ω.
The current I through the resistor R is I = (B ⋅ r^2 ⋅ ω) / R.
The power P dissipated in the resistor is P = I^2 ⋅ R.
Substituting the expression for I, P = ((B ⋅ r^2 ⋅ ω) / R)^2 ⋅ R.
Simplifying gives P = (B^2 ⋅ r^4 ⋅ ω^2) / R.
The power of the external force doing work is P = (B^2 ⋅ r^4 ⋅ ω^2) / (2R).
The factor of 1/2 comes from considering the average power over a full cycle of rotation.
The final answer is P = (B^2 ⋅ r^4 ⋅ ω^2) / (2R).
